revision.text:
{{Infobox company | logo= | name =New Relic | type=[[Private Company]] | industry= [[Application performance management]] | foundation=2008 | location_city=[[San Francisco, CA]] | location_country=[[United States]] | key_people=[[Lew Cirne]] | website=[http://newrelic.com/ newrelic.com] }} '''New Relic''' is an [[application performance management]] (APM) company based in San Francisco, California. [[Lew Cirne]], known as the inventor of application performance management,<ref>{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Derrick|title=Startup Strategies: How Lew Cirne Made New Relic a SaaS Success|url=http://gigaom.com/cloud/startup-strategies-how-lew-cirne-made-new-relic-a-saas-success/|publisher=GigaOM}}</ref> founded New Relic in 2008 and currently acts as the company's CEO.<ref>{{cite web|title=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/new-relic|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/new-relic}}</ref> New Relic's APM solution is delivered in a [[software as a service]] (SaaS) model.<ref>{{cite web|title=http://bizcloudnetwork.com/saas-apm-review|url=http://bizcloudnetwork.com/saas-apm-review}}</ref> New Relic's APM solution can monitor [[Application software|applications]] that are running in [[Cloud computing|cloud]], on-premise, or hybrid environments.
== Technical Capabilities ==
New Relic currently provides the following APM capabilities:
* Performance Analytics: New Relic supports the following languages and frameworks with application agent technology: [[Ruby (programming language)|Ruby]], [[Ruby on Rails|Rails]], [[PHP]], [[Java (programming language)|Java]], [[.NET Framework|.Net]], [[Python (programming language)|Python]]. * [[Real user monitoring|Real User Monitoring]]: Monitors the page ready and loaded events critical to page performance and user perception, as well as derived network latency, with a tie back to the server-side transaction trace.<ref>{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Derrick|title=New Relic Now Monitors User Experience in Real Time|url=http://gigaom.com/cloud/new-relic-now-monitors-user-experience-in-real-time/|publisher=GigaOM}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Taft|first=Darryl|title=New Relic adds Real User Monitoring|url=http://www.eweek.com/c/a/Enterprise-Applications/New-Relic-Adds-Real-User-Monitoring-734110/|publisher=eWeek}}</ref> * Server Monitoring: New Relic monitors the server resources with an operating system resident agent. Resources such as [[CPU]], [[Memory (computers)|Memory]], [[Disk storage|Disk]] and [[Computer network|Network]], of the servers running the application being managed <ref>{{cite web|last=Gohring|first=Nancy|title=New Relic Now Monitors Server Performance|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/243427/new_relic_now_monitors_server_performance.html#tk.rss_news|publisher=IDG News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Derrick|title=New Relic Adds Server Monitoring to its SaaS Mix|url=http://gigaom.com/cloud/new-relic-adds-server-monitoring-to-its-saas-mix/|publisher=GigaOM}}</ref> * SQL/[[NoSQL]] performance monitoring * Web application transaction tracing * Thresholds and alert notifications * Deployment history * Availability monitoring * Application architecture maps * Scalability analysis * Service level reports * Java profiling * Automatic application discovery and instrumentation
===Programming languages=== * [[Ruby (programming language)|Ruby]] * [[Java (programming language)|Java]] * [[.net|.NET]] * [[PHP]] * [[Python (programming language)|Python]] * Play 2.0
==CA Technologies vs New Relic== On November 5, 2012, [[CA Technologies]] (formerly Computer Associates) filed a lawsuit in the US District Court for the Eastern District in New York. The lawsuit claims that New Relic violated three patents that came into CA Technologies' possession through acquisitions. The three patents in question are numbers 7,225,361 B2; 7,512,935 B1; and 7,797,580 B2.<ref>{{cite web|last=Morgan|first=Timothy|title=CA Technologies sues New Relic over APM patents|url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/11/06/ca_sues_new_relic_apm_patents/|publisher=The Register|accessdate=13 November 2012}}</ref>
